item.title: A Guide to Iran’s Presidential Election
item.description: A look at the three main candidates in Friday’s presidential election and how this election is different from the 2009 vote.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times

item.title: Syria Has Used Chemical Arms on Rebels, U.S. and Allies Find
item.description: The assessment will put added pressure on a deeply divided Obama administration to develop a response to a provocation that the president has declared a “red line.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI, MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK LANDLER

item.title: Syria Has Used Chemical Arms on Rebels, U.S. and Allies Find
item.description: The assessment will put added pressure on a deeply divided Obama administration to develop a response to a provocation that the president has declared a “red line.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI, MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK LANDLER

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 13
item.description: Turkish protests and Europe; gay lobby in the Vatican; Brussels pushes trade deal with Washington; e-cigarettes and regulators; Kanye west reflects on his career; soccer and politics in Iran.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Why the Protests Have Changed Turkey Forever
item.description: After Prime Minister Erdogan’s order to clear the park that has been the scene of two weeks of protests, The Times’s Sebnem Arsu tells Marcus Mabry that Turkey and Turkish politics will never be the same.
item.dc:creator: By MARCUS MABRY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Can N.S.A. Surveillance Be Likened to Chinese Spying?
item.description: Amid a report that the N.S.A. gathered communications from China, state media have begun to speak out; others ask if gathering commercial and military secrets, and surveillance to stop terrorist attacks, can even be likened.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A picture of Edward Snowden, a former C.I.A. employee who leaked top-secret documents about sweeping U.S. surveillance programs, on the front page of South China Morning Post at a news stand in Hong Kong.

item.title: Younger Iranians Feel Like Outsiders Before Elections
item.description: A day before the presidential election, many of the generation born after the revolution say their viewpoints are ignored.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A woman walks past posters of a presidential candidate, Ali Akbar Velayati.

item.title: Czech Police Raid Government Offices
item.description: Several officials, including a top aide to the prime minister, are reported to have been detained. The coalition government has been rocked by a series of corruption scandals.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Petr Necas said in a statement on Thursday that he had no intention of resigning from his post after the police raids.

item.title: Hague Court Declines Inquiry Into Church Abuse Cover-Up
item.description: Victims sought to prosecute Benedict XVI and others for what they called a worldwide cover-up of sexual abuse amounting to “crimes against humanity.”
item.category: Survivors Network of Those Abused by Priests
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN

item.title: Another Garment Factory Scare in Bangladesh
item.description: A fire at a plant in Ashulia raised new questions about safety conditions less than two months after the collapse of a factory building claimed more than 1,100 lives.
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and JIM YARDLEY

item.title: New Exhibit at Auschwitz-Birkenau Honors Children of the Holocaust
item.description: A multimedia exhibit that tries to push visitors beyond their knowledge of the facts of the Nazis’ Final Solution was dedicated on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel found the name of Judith, the twin sister of his father-in-law, among the Book of Names exhibit at Auschwitz-Birkenau on Thursday.

item.title: Syrian Death Toll Approaches 93,000, U.N. Says
item.description: Navi Pillay, the United Nations human rights chief, said the figure is probably understated and called for an end to the violence.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Zimbabwe Sets Short Timetable for Elections
item.description: President Robert G. Mugabe’s decree raises fears that the election will be a repeat of the country’s disastrous 2008 vote.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: The country’s longtime president, Robert G. Mugabe, center, during a parade in the capital of Harare on Thursday.

item.title: Way of the World: Eye-Opener for the Elite on Inequity
item.description: At a TED conference, gloom replaced the normal sunny-side up view of capitalism's future.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

item.title: Mob Attacks Afghan Doctor and Female Patient
item.description: A doctor was attacked and stoned because he and his female patient had been found in an examining room without a chaperon, Afghan officials said.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: India Ink: What’s Behind the Declining Rupee
item.description: An Indian economist at a credit rating agency explains the causes.
item.dc:creator: By MADAN SABNAVIS
item.media:description: A bank cashier receiving Indian currency from a customer at a bank in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Nov. 22, 2011.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Kurds Uneasy About Turkish Protests
item.description: Although some Kurds have expressed support for Turkey’s protest movement, the minority community is worried that the anti-government mood could undermine a fragile peace deal and even strengthen its enemies.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: A demonstrator with a Kurdish flag in Taksim Square in Istanbul on Wednesday.

item.title: Sentiment Builds in China to Press Claim for Okinawa
item.description: A semiofficial campaign has gathered steam to question Japanese rule over the Ryukyu chain, including the strategic island that is home to 27,000 American troops.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Anti-Japan demonstrations outside the Japanese embassy in Beijing in September.

item.title: Greek Workers Strike to Protest Shutdown of State Broadcaster
item.description: The action was called by unions to protest the surprise decision by the government to close the state broadcaster, putting around 2,900 employees out of work.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: India Ink: Maoists Attack Passenger Train in Bihar
item.description: A soldier and a passenger were killed in the attack near Jamui in Bihar on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Turkish Protesters Get ‘Final’ Warning to Clear Out of Park
item.description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said the use of force was justified against demonstrators occupying an Istanbul park.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Turkish Leader Offers Referendum on Park at Center of Protests
item.description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan offered to hold a referendum to decide the fate of the park in central Istanbul that has become the locus of protests against his government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Chinese Media Suggest N.S.A. Disclosure Will Hurt U.S. Ties
item.description: The reports in state media are the closest thing to an official Chinese response to the revelations, which have come at an uncomfortable time for the United States.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY and DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Charges Urged in Filipino Raid on Taiwanese Boat
item.description: The killing of a Taiwanese fisherman by the crew of a Philippine Coast Guard vessel has strained relations between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: India Ink: Central Park Dreams Trigger a Battle in Mumbai
item.description: The expiration of a 99-year old lease has unleashed a debate over the legacy of the Mumbai racecourse.
item.dc:creator: By VAISHNAVI CHANDRASHEKHAR
item.media:description: A view of the promenade along the Arabian Sea in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on July 5, 2012.
